output: Mr. President, dear colleagues, I once again apologize for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of everyone and the perception that education, knowledge, and the interweaving of different cultures with one another are crucial are already considered a given.
For this very reason, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its part, and in this new perspective, a new regulation is already in place.

The Erasmus Mundus program constitutes a significant contribution to the creation of centers of excellence in the EU, which to some extent will help stem the brain drain from the European Union. It also plays a notable role in...

in promoting European values among nationals from third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent a cultural and linguistic diversity that serves as an attractive and distinct pole compared to models existing in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have struggled greatly to survive.

The issue of visas for Erasmus Mundus students and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them often lead to a situation of semi-limbo within the European Union, as they pursue their master's degrees but on tourist visas, and sometimes even overstayed.
It is of the utmost relevance and urgency to seek a solution that ensures solidity, transparency, and effectiveness in the issuance of pre-student visas.
Knowledge of the language that enables cultural appreciation and mutual coexistence, beyond strict academic proficiency, is also crucial, which is why we can absolutely guarantee this premise.
To conclude, a word of thanks to Deputy Sarnez for the manner in which she steered this entire process and for the balanced report she has produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the granting of state aids for the modernization and renewal of the fishing fleets of the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009 or should be in force for an indefinite period.
The specific characteristics of fishing activities in these regions warrant the extension of such aid beyond 2009, without causing any significant harm to the marine environment.
Assistance aimed at the modernization and renewal of the fleets in the outermost regions for an indefinite period does not imply permanent and internal aids.
would be immediately discontinued if studies and assessment by the Scientific Council and Regional Advisory Boards highlighted such a need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fisheries in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that underpin for fishermen from each RUP an exclusive fishing reserve up to the seed also justify differentiated treatment regarding aids for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, the Fisheries Committee has found the best solutions that can take into account the specific characteristics of fisheries in the outermost regions.

Mr. President, Mr. President, Commissioner Almunia, President of the Eurogroup, I would like to congratulate not only the rapporteurs but also the Commission for the initiative of producing this text, the review of the ten years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
This is a strategic text, and this analysis was crucial.
The euro, as has been stated here today, is an undeniable success.

Lisbon to Helsinki, Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has proven its resilience and strength even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed, and it is clearly important that the borders of this club be expanded.
But the times we live in put the solidity of the European project to the test on a daily basis in many other dimensions.
The euro, as mentioned, is a central instrument in the functioning of the financial system.

However, the Commission's text itself clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in terms of both social and spatial aspects, kept pace with this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have violently intensified during the single currency's decade of operation.
This divergence affects regions in my country, in particular, northern Portugal, but also other regions of member states.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, notably through the extremely high exchange rate, have affected more severely the regions that are most exposed to international competition and the most export-oriented regions.
Today, the crisis that resulted from the deregulation of financial markets is violently impacting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation of many citizens and regions.

These regions, those exposed to international competition, those reliant on small and medium-sized enterprises, where access to credit is most crucial, are today victims of this process and are even threatening depression.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the confidence placed in it by European citizens.
The most powerful European countries have already initiated the process of revitalizing their national economies.
We have the particular case of initiatives related to the automotive industry.
But in Europe, it is more than that.
It must be far more than a more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
It is time to make the euro a central tool for Europe, supporting a strong currency but also a robust real economy, and to ensure the proper functioning of the euro.
of mechanisms that ensure the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it lies at the heart, it is the core of the European project.
Debates on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area now have an undisputable and heightened impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon strategy, which is a sum of national initiatives, and a stability and growth pact that differently tightens the various countries that use it and that they must submit to, are limitations compounded by the limited budget we have.
Crises generate opportunities.
A monetary union can only be sustained by a convergence of the well-being of the member countries that make it up, regardless of their citizens, regardless of where they were born.
What other way could we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, and that is why we eagerly await the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this Plenary on November 26th and present to European citizens.

It is essential that, emerging from this crisis, a new phase of the Union be launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by effective prosperity made up of cohesion and also economic citizenship.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, this oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Gagliotti, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development of this Parliament, is fully justified and relevant.

In fact, it is necessary to clarify the reasons that lead the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund, insofar as it is unable to reach an agreement on a common position that would allow the legislative process to continue.
It is difficult to uncover the motives that may underlie the Council's position, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
Does the Council not desire a more agile and immediate response to the natural disasters that occur?
I do not want this type of rapid response to be the norm for other kinds of catastrophes, such as severe industrial accidents, terrorist attacks, or serious public health situations.

It is important that these issues have a clear response, just as it is important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and whether it intends to take any action to unlock the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this domain.
Citizens would not understand fully if we did not act this way.
I wish to protest against the statement made by Ms Lulling, which seeks to influence the vote of Members in this House. Such influence is unwarranted.

The interpretation you are making is one that we do not share, and it is in this regard that I would like to ask colleagues who know what they are addressing, who are aware that we are upholding different interests, namely the interests of public health, the interests of citizens, and the interests of countries that indeed vote in favor of the report.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, for two months now, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Lisbon Treaty are barely reported in the media.

Don't you think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be strengthened with the necessity and urgency of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, also as a political response to address and overcome the crisis we are living through?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, the world's powers currently have the international financial system under their control.
They seek a hand detail, and it was about time.
And, therefore, perhaps it is time for us to finally address another problem that we have been hearing about for decades.
For decades, we have heard this music of the ignoble plundering of resources, how many times, as again now in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe it is also time to pursue these companies, to target this despicable trade, to freeze the accounts through which the shameful profits from this mineral exploitation, at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations, flow and are deposited.
I fail to understand why these companies are not listed in the same manner as we have already blacklisted terrorist organizations.

And I fail to understand why the international community is unable to pursue these businessmen who, in reality, are not businessmen at all, but genuine criminals who threaten regional and global security.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to develop an international initiative in this regard.
We heard it said several times here today that a crisis typically generates an opportunity, and so it is.
And if we want to seize the opportunity that is presented to us, the agenda is straightforward to understand.
Firstly, as we know, at the European Union level, there is a need to introduce transparency mechanisms, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
And it is not necessary for your commissioner Macri to launch further consultations, nor is it required for the Presidency to examine and invoke additional studies.
There are more proposals, one need only look at the proposals that were timely made by the socialists and many of which were eventually taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot exist in a global space passively.
She must be an active agent in shaping the new international order, she must be the advocate of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are currently the tax havens.
Thirdly, we heard here today, Mr President of the Commission, that there is a reluctance to coordinate strategies at the level of the different states.
It is true that, if we had not heard from many members of the Commission, for so long, that markets self-regulate, that the state should keep out.
that financial markets have no impact on growth or employment, there might be a more active and engaged spirit of solidarity among the different countries.
But today the proposal we have before us is merely a first step. If we compare it to the programs of China and the United States, on the other hand, it...
does not define clearly enough what the objective is, and the objective must be employment, and thirdly, because a European program cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time to show Europe's citizens that Europe is a network of economic rights that protects them in times of crisis, in terms of
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that, at this moment, are not receiving the benefits of the interventions made in the banking sector.
The real economy is precisely this, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is also here, and above all, because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I appear before you to present the work that has been done in collaboration with all of you in this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the development of this process, we can say that we have done our job.

to all, and in particular to the shadow rapporteurs from the various political groups who worked hard to reach compromises for the future, to the regional development staff always available, especially Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa da Fara,

To the PSE staff, Lilla, and Petros, to the European Commission, which, always represented by the many diverse directorates-general that such an outstanding report requires, continuously and closely monitored the work and made great efforts to ensure its successful completion.
To my office and, most particularly, to Joana Benziño, I extend my most sincere thanks on behalf of a more harmonious and structured development for coastal regions and tourism in the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union collectively possess over 89,000 kilometers of coastal zones.

This presents a variety of very particular features that, according to their location, stand out either for their cosmopolitanism, if we were talking about cities such as Lisbon, Copenhagen, or Stockholm, or

the challenges of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with issues of connectivity to major urban areas or rapid desertification contexts, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands, or Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of a coast and coastal zone, and experiences daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with them.
According to data available up to 2010, approximately 75% of humanity will live in coastal zones. These areas
According to the circuits and their interrelations, we define the 50 kilometers in a straight line that extend from the coastline to the inland areas.
Yes, regions and not maritime strips detached from an integrated vision that these matters so desperately need, and that our ancestors would also endorse.
Here, this entire population will converge in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, with the sole expectation that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated vision of the impact of tourism on coastal areas seized our minds and prompted us to take action.

In the current financial crisis context, where the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal manner.

The regions, which for their development have an overwhelming or total dependence on this, see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust, especially since tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, coordinated measures can and should be taken, and the spirit in which the Treaty of Lisbon is imbued reflects this very trend.
However, waiting until the Treaty's entry into force to take action is akin to waiting until the point where we will be lamenting spilled milk.
The current political and tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it demand from us urgent and effective action.

The fact that these are structurally dependent areas on tourism, as a job creator, even though it is often seasonal employment, this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

For this very reason, this report that we present to you here and now, which was already of the greatest relevance and urgency when the Regional Development Committee of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it should be considered a priority from this moment onward for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority should indeed be given to the numerous initiatives this entails, as well as those that receive its explicit support and have already been communicated by other institutions, in addition to the measures taken in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, of which I would highlight the revision of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock it is currently experiencing should obviously be addressed.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of these coastal areas' economies, guaranteeing their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the genuine integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transportation,

energy, the cohesion instruments already in place, the new quality product policy that the CAP revision incorporates with the announcement of the EFSC report, and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an adequate and holistic vision for this policy should be a reality in the European Union in the near future.

And, to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and swift and effective action involving all partners already on the ground can we ensure that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and future-oriented coastal tourism sector.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, eJustice is a significant step in accessing the law, justice, and the courts.
I would like to congratulate the initiative, commend the rapporteur, and the French Presidency.

The EJSTIS was one of the projects under discussion, and it calls on Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of a pilot project that will enable all citizens to access the services of other Member States in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable, and native language manner.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice on cross-border and legal issues.
e-Justice should be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions from the various Member States and ensure their integration with this responsible unit.
Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I welcome the launch of the portal in December 2009.
Mr. President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, Mrs. Martin Rühi, and the other members of the Parliament.
In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation setting standards for security features and biometric data in passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now, we have had to take new steps to combat the abduction and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, can be the fundamental means of winning this difficult and important battle.

In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children as young as six is already a practice with a long tradition, which, perhaps for this reason, does not raise any objections from me.
As an advocate for the European cause, I believe that, on this matter, harmonization is important.
It reassures me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long set the minimum age at six years for the collection of fingerprints, will not have to change their national legislation.
It should be emphasized that the security of passports, which is being strengthened today, does not end with the existence of the passport itself.

The passport, in and of itself, corresponds to an increase in security levels, ranging from the presentation of the necessary documents for passport issuance, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border control points.
This report is another step towards affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Alexander Lambsdorff, and the shadow rapporteurs, with special mention to Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I deem it indispensable that we move towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must effectively move forward with the specificities and necessary precautions towards applying the essential rules of the internal market to defense industries, increasing transparency in the tenders organized and the contracts signed involving the Member States of the European Union.
But, at the same time, we must contribute to the development of conditions that enable greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in global markets.

It seems important to me that this directive can ensure progress in the legal framework concerning public contracts in the fields of defense and security, advancing the construction of the internal market.

internal and obviously respecting the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security and in particular those that manufacture arms, ammunition, and security equipment, such as, for example, my own country.

I would also emphasize the provisions that enable easier access for small and medium-sized enterprises to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thereby making greater progress with more impact and depth.

industrial for the creation of a true European market in the defense industries, which can also contribute to strengthening research and development, not only in the defense industries but also in a range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defense industries.
To conclude, one can refer to the obvious articulation between defense industries and the Union's foreign policies.
But I would like to cite, regarding DETA, a recent intervention, translating a classic Romanian proverb: "If you want peace, prepare for war."

The European Union, being almost a peaceful superpower, we refer to these industries as defense industries rather than war industries, because we seek peace and not war, and thus also require defense industries.
Vice President Barrot, I agree with you, and I do so with dissatisfaction.
In fact, we must be dissatisfied with the set of measures that are extensive.
The truth is that irregular immigration to Europe persists, human trafficking continues, and there are areas where the situation is highly critical.

With regard to immigration, specifically in the Mediterranean region towards Italy, France has initiated a series of important bilateral cooperations, but other Member States are not having an impact.
It is necessary for the Commission to persist without losing enthusiasm in this policy of cooperation and aid to the United States.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I will attempt to present the issues in a highly concise manner.
First point, the issue of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for the tests, which concluded, as has been mentioned here, on December 31, 2008.
There is a need, Commissioner, for the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, similar to what occurs in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against potential unfair practices, and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I requested his attention to this matter, similar to what other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety standards, social standards, and environmental standards.
The RITES, for example, is a recent initiative that imposes even more restrictions on us.
It is important that the Commission have a clear strategy that is visible and subject to monitoring to ensure that imported products meet identical requirements.
In what ways are these aspects being adequately addressed in the ongoing free trade agreements?
As for Meidine, can Meidine actually help to resolve this issue?
Third point: The European Union has launched an economic recovery plan to tackle the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this moment, what actions is the Commission preparing to take as a series of other countries, such as China, are increasingly proliferating the implementation of non-tariff barriers to prevent our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What proposals do you put forward regarding the update or adjustment of the Globalization Fund, as well as the support available within the structural funds frameworks, to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Final question, indeed, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner, I am finishing up, raise awareness among her colleagues and the institutions dealing with European monetary policy to rebalance their monetary system?
It is clear to us that we should applaud Obama's decision, the decision to close Guantánamo, to ban torture, illegal interrogations, and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese Socialist Government do not feel any guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the opposite.

It was precisely now, under Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese Government, and at the initiative of Minister Luiz Amado, that the possibility and duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without conviction in Guantánamo was triggered.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the other Member States of the European Union. It is crucial that tomorrow the resolution is approved by all the parties that make up this House so that, united, the decision can have more strength.
Mr. President, thank you very much to colleague Napolitano for the excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with heads of government deciding together.
All with a desire to do more and better, a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace in the world.
Following them solely from an economic and business perspective is a clear mistake.

Responding to growth crises naturally requires political action, but addressing humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must provide answers to the world's problems.
The world demanded answers, and months later, we, citizens and politicians alike, on a platform such as the Union for the Mediterranean, continue to be slow in our response.

I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served as a learning opportunity and a chance to move forward, for only those who make mistakes learn, but speeding up the reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest in adopting this directive proposal lies primarily in how it can contribute to stimulating economic activity at the local level and supporting social initiatives.

This application of a reduced rate holds significant importance in the housing sector, encompassing both construction and renovation. It enables Member States that adopt it to decrease the respective cost for the end-user.

The provision of local services, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the cost of living, ensuring and creating more and better jobs by promoting the consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.

The restoration activity, fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the very increase of tourism, can thus benefit significantly at the local level from this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate in the European internal market, which will help reduce the reservations of some Member States already observed at the Council level.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, regardless of the pretext.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament must not provide an opportunity for governments with certain reservations about the European Commission's proposal to effectively exercise their right of veto, which European legislation still reserves for tax matters.
Thus, here it is prudent to reject major changes, which only hinder the acceptance of the text.
As already mentioned here, not only is the excellent the enemy of the good, but he who wants everything loses everything.
This proposed directive is significant not only for the strengthening of local economies but also aligns with the ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.
Let us therefore support the Commission's proposal as presented. Indeed, this was the intent of the vote, as I agree with the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee.

I welcome the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it was presented by the Commission and voted on in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.
I took the floor to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrella, and indeed, it was this that motivated me to speak. It was when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The issue is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that seek to defend them, women who are ignored, scorned, discriminated against because they want to dedicate themselves to their families, and we do not listen to them.
And this is a matter of freedom, a matter of the freedom of choice that the left so often likes to invoke, but which it overlooks here.
It is a matter of respecting or not the freedom of organization of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who wish to do so with a higher quality of life, more quality fatherhood, and more quality motherhood.
That is what our society also needs to do.
We will not get there, we will not solve the problems of people's birth rates and happiness with prejudices.
We resolve with policies tailored to reality and the spontaneous desires of people.
We are not going there as an opposition to the state and the market.
Let's take a fair look at the family.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the difficult situation at Quimonda was exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has been doing everything it deems appropriate and necessary to help resolve the situation.
We would like the Bavarian government to also demonstrate a high sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, affirmed the great interest in making this company viable, which is so important for Portugal and for Europe, stating that Aquimonda can be a competitive company at a global level.
Mr. President, the Portuguese Government's efforts will continue towards a solution that ensures the company's viability.
We expect the German governments, at both the federal and state levels, to engage effectively in resolving this issue.
As for me, I would like to underscore once again the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry on European soil.
that no national or state executive makes the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs within the territory of the Union.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to support the restructuring of major automotive industry groups, but the funds of the Union and the efforts of the European Commission cannot be exhausted by such aid.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, we call on Commissioner Vladimir Spila, with whom we share professional and political ties, and President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and that of a significant portion of Quimonda's workers, to commit the Commission to supporting Quimonda, overcoming any potential communication gaps.

We should emphasize, before concluding, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was new hope regarding Qimonda and also highlighted the importance, as already mentioned by colleagues, of the economic sector in which Qimonda operates.
We take into account that, as soon as the Portuguese government expresses its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, considering the country's economic size.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save Quimonda, time is of the essence.

Madam President, Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we live in may not be the most appropriate for discussing the Lisbon Strategy, but there is no doubt that we need a strategy.
in a strategy that addresses the difficulties and challenges presented by the current crisis.
And that is what we also expect from the Commission.

It is indispensable that the Commission does not deviate from this matter and, instead, has the capacity to articulate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the German-speaking countries.

It is indispensable to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has already been stated here, that is of interest to Europe due to its quality and value, the research it conducts, and the environmental quality also associated with it. It is indispensable that the Commission does not withdraw.
I endorse the invitation made by my colleague Pineda for his commissioner and the Commission to visit Portugal.

It is indispensable that the Commission bear in mind that, at this juncture, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from European authorities. They need to feel that European authorities are close at hand.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands; instead, they desire a Europe that has the audacity to roll up its sleeves and get to work, aiding in overcoming difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, I too would like to associate myself with the tributes paid to Jammeh, but I have asked to speak to congratulate your President on the statement he made regarding the European Day of Remembrance for Victims of Terrorism.
It was at my initiative that, five years ago, we adopted this approach, which the Council endorsed at a meeting on 25 March, in the wake of the tragic Madrid attacks.
But my intervention was an appeal.
The Parliament has always been faithful in celebrating this date, but unfortunately, this date has not yet received, among the European institutions and Member States, the prominence it deserves.
I believe that the commemoration of this date is one of the most important tools we have to honor the victims, as your President did, but also to raise public awareness.
I know that there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but little else.
Consequently, the appeal I make to the Commission, to the Czech Presidency, is that all Member States duly celebrate this date in the future.
(FEL) Ladies and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we anticipated, and unemployment will be higher than we foresaw.
There are good reasons to suppose that the anticipated European stimulus is insufficient, but it is already clear at this moment that it is taking far too long to reach citizens.
The position of the Parliament is strong and clear; it has been and I hope it continues to be so.
Our goal is to preserve jobs and create new ones, with cohesion and solidarity, both territorial and social.
And in this time of crisis, citizens cannot accept a Europe that does not provide answers, a Europe that is powerless before the problems they are facing.
What is it that the Parliament will ask the Commission?

It naturally requests, through these reports, that you coordinate national interventions, urging you to use all means currently at your disposal to intervene and providing you with all the necessary conditions, as a budgetary entity, to make this happen.

Request that he launch a clear European initiative for employment and tell him that it is important to have a timed agenda to implement financial market regulatory measures, as well as to get credit flowing to the real economy.
But what is it that is asked of the council?
The Council is asked, above all, to rediscover the political will that lies at the heart of building the European project.
The European Union is about competition, but it is equally about cohesion and solidarity.
And there cannot be a single market without this guarantee of solidarity and cohesion.
It is for this reason that we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies we had prior to joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, anyone visiting sub-Saharan Africa can easily recognize in most countries the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations these services should serve.
The indicators continuously published at the international level never cease to confirm this.
And, in that respect, it is utterly disturbing to realize that simple gestures and even not very elaborate practices, not particularly costly, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard, and we must always bear in mind that cooperation in the health sector is truly strategic and directly addresses not only one of the Millennium Goals but many of the Millennium Goals.

The Court of Auditors found that community financing in favor of the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite commitments made by the Commission regarding the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in Sub-Saharan Africa.

It seems there might be a typo in your Portuguese text. The word "Fincita-se" doesn't appear to be a standard Portuguese term. However, if it's intended to be "Fincar-se," which means "to firmly establish oneself" or "to fixate oneself," then the translation would be:

**"One establishes oneself firmly."**

Please confirm if this is the correct interpretation or if there was a different word intended.

And it acknowledged, I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to the establishment of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but it did not extend the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was foreseen as one of its priorities.
(FEL) Fine citation.

According to the Court, this occurred again because the Commission did not have sufficient expertise in health matters to ensure that the financing of aid granted to this sector was used in the best way.
I finished this.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors directly issues to the European Commission, and which I support.
For our part, I wish to reiterate this same challenge, now sustained by the objectivity of these data and this evaluation.
Health services already form part of, but should increasingly become a greater part of, our development assistance priorities, warranting an increase in their funding.

Optimizing the way aid is delivered, bearing in mind the seemingly contradictory needs for coordination in its management and proximity to beneficiary populations, is to provide a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this appeal, and it is in this spirit that I urge it.
Colleague Bowis, just a moment ago, delivered a moving speech here and was able to put human faces to the cold, dry figures of the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be able to put a look of joy and hope in those very faces.
And for that, Madam Commissioner, it is indispensable that the health figures in our cooperation be different.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is truly distressing.
It is a country that has experienced chronic instability for many years, which embarked on a path towards democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well, there was a coup d'état, a small internal war, and the country lives in great political, military, and tension-filled instability, with deep rivalries. Recently, there has also been a very concerning and increasingly evident presence of drug trafficking for all interested observers.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the bomb assassination of Chief of Staff Tagme Naouye, and also the murder, in particularly barbaric, if not savage, terms of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity with their families, the people of Guinea-Bissau, and we mourn and strongly condemn these attacks.
We wish for a return to normality, and the lesson I draw and would like to emphasize in the resolution is that impunity is not a solution.
In the past, regarding the assassination of Assumane Mané and General Alvares M. Ciabra, how was it that the eyes were turned away from finding and bringing the guilty parties to justice?
It is evident that this is not possible.

Consequently, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that the perpetrators must be identified, the guilty parties must be brought to justice, and we must provide all the assistance that is necessary.

I would also like to draw attention, in conclusion, to the concern with which we have witnessed the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk it already represents for the European Union, and the shocking presence, given its evidentiality, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal for a closer relationship with Cape Verde in this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable, and this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the strengthening of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also highly important in this context, thank you very much.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would first and foremost like to thank everyone for the work accomplished.

The three lines defined in the Green Book—concentration, interconnection, and cooperation—can provide solutions to certain obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with

concentration of economic activity, inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance, and the divisions imposed by borders between Member States, especially the most disadvantaged ones, but also between regions.
We should, therefore, enhance the synergies between these policies through effective methods of assessing their territorial impact.

For this very reason, I have always advocated for the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators, with the aim of improving the allocation and implementation of corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, GDP remains the sole eligibility criterion for receiving support from the Structural Funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the conduct of territorial assessments should not lead to more bureaucracy or delays, but rather to simplification, the implementation of new policies, and support actions for territorial cohesion.
The fifth interim report, and finally, Mr. President, makes specific reference to the transition regions situated between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is important to note that these regions require a clearer status, with greater security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, in the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I cannot fail to mention the very specific problems of the outermost regions.

Regions that, due to the conjunction and persistence of a certain number of geographical factors, exhibit great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in the context of a severe international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would therefore like to appeal to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Hübner, to pay very close attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, namely in tourism, construction, and the rise in unemployment, would be crucial to enable a specific European response tailored to these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions, going beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for the majority of European regions.
a specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the plan for the European economy's recovery states that cohesion policy significantly contributes to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovering from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon strategy, aiming to achieve growth and employment.
All the activated instruments aim to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this regard, the extension of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the streamlining of the European Social Fund are particularly responsible for addressing the multiple social and economic emergency situations that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be all the more effective if your actions and areas of focus have been complementary.

However, since no new funds or new lines of action on the ground were foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in combating unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressure in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Committee on Rules has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.
Urgency was requested of us, however, on this matter, and in adopting this regulatory package, we took this into account. This cause has never shirked its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the many perspectives that the current situation raises, and considering the guarantees of process efficiency and the real benefits for citizens that the proposal aims to achieve, we abstain from presenting new proposals and amendments at this time.
However, we caution that there is a need to initiate, from this moment onwards, an evaluation process of this fund, with a view to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible.
The crisis, among other aspects, has highlighted the significant imbalances among the eurozone countries, perhaps the main source of tension.
conclusion of the report on the Economic and Monetary Union, but above all, the extreme vulnerability of the countries that, while belonging to the European Union, are not part of the eurozone.

Therefore, the strengthening of the resources available at European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely indispensable. Hence, we welcome the increase from 12 to 25, and then to 50 million euros in necessary resources.
However, the most important thing is to address the root causes of problems, not just their most evident manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the euro area must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to assess, in this light, the capacity of European horizontal policies, but it is also essential to revisit new financing instruments, such as eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. President-in-Office, we are facing an unprecedented crisis.

In fact, this was not the time to discuss internally how to organize ourselves. Therefore, my hope is that the Lisbon Treaty will be ratified quickly so that we can face the global scene united and in solidarity, as Europeans.

Regarding the economic crisis, in the report I authored and which this Parliament largely approved, it was acknowledged that the recovery plan subsequently presented by the Commission might not be sufficient.
Today, we are certain that it is not enough.
A crisis that began financially spreads to the real economy, then to employment, and subsequently to the social sphere.
It is not sufficient and it is blurred.

This is the opportunity for the Commission to address the real issues of Europeans through serious financial regulation, rather than the lightest and most piecemeal approach, which is that of the European Parliament.

where possible, as it is currently underway, not in fact from individualistic national plans, but from a true European initiative, not through scattered means, but by focusing on the real challenge that I am addressing.

In every crisis lies an opportunity, and this is the opportunity for the Commission and Europe to address the genuine concerns of European citizens. I hope this will be realized through a fresh approach to the recovery plan.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as many members have already done, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese EPP members, our great satisfaction with the outcome of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe this clearly strengthens the development and evolution prospects of the European Union, creating conditions for a new stage.

We would naturally like to congratulate all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President present here, and also, of course, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, which

You have a very important role here, and so we also wanted to say with pleasure that we note that despite all these vicissitudes and while we still await with anticipation the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see their capital's name linked.

This is a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union, and I would like to say that, from this perspective, we can also count on another flag, which will always be a flag of the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP, namely the flag of the national parliaments.
We argue that the Treaty of Lisbon takes a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national parliaments into European democracy as well.

And therefore, we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, namely the representative dimension, and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendum dimension.

If the fundamental and essential aspect of democracy is representation, not direct voting, the Treaty of Lisbon is also a significant step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, a brief intervention to welcome the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to emphasize the decisive role played by Fine Gael and its leader, and soon-to-be Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, in taking the lead on this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became very apparent.
It is we, all of us, who are the primary beneficiaries of all the Union's actions.
It is fundamental that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our lives on a daily basis.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
It is certainly the case with the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be, simultaneously, a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having concluded a far too lengthy debate on its organization and functioning, can now focus much more intently, with new and far more effective tools, on the genuine problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth, and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal aimed at future generations.

Considering the information gap regarding the values, competencies, objectives, and mode of operation of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new compulsory subject of European studies.
In an objective, truthful, and concrete manner, European youth will effectively learn about our principles, who we are, what we do, and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge, from a young age, that they will understand throughout their lives the potential and immense utility of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you on this initial debate on what this new political control instrument means for the progress and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to benefit.

In light of the most recent developments, the Irish referendum, ratification by Poland, and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I ask what your assessment is of the process for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
There have been efforts on the part of the Commission's President.
and what is the forecast for an eventual date of entry into force of the treaty and, on the other hand, to know if at this moment and due to this forecast, the Commission
Some steps have been taken to transition from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or it is still in a phase of, let's say, expectation, therefore, in a wait-and-see phase.

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following at this stage when everyone is awaiting the formation of the Commission: fundamentally, what is the perspective that the President holds?

It remains to be seen whether we will now have, until this moment of final ratification by the Czech Republic, a commission in caretaker capacity or whether they will proceed with the appointment procedures for the new commissioners.

Mr. President, it is fundamental that the primary objective of the establishment of the European External Action Service fulfills the efforts of the European institutions to ensure the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It should also represent more than the sum of its parts, it should be an added value compared to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this regard, it seems essential to me that what defines the specificity of the Union be at the heart of this new reality, and that specificity is the community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which advocates and safeguards a close articulation between the Commission and the future Service.

In this regard, I would like to emphasize two aspects: the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, who is also a Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure effectiveness and smooth operation.

Lastly, there is a need for an alliance between the Parliament and the Commission to combat the intergovernmental drift that is looming and which could jeopardize the effective functioning of the service.
The Parliament must, therefore, remain vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a center of excellence, representing the best expertise in foreign policy matters.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, first and foremost, I wish to emphasize the importance of this issue raised by Member Gloriano, as it is a matter of the most fundamental justice.

We all know perfectly well that, in a situation of an A flu pandemic, it will be the southern countries that will suffer the most from this problem and the consequences of the virus's proliferation, not the northern countries.

And every year, with total passivity, we witness the death of millions of citizens, both male and female, as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or are treatable in the countries of the North. An immense list of malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis,
We have no limits for this list and passively witness this issue.

We effectively use the southern countries as free suppliers of samples of new virus strains so that we can improve treatment in the northern countries. However, despite all this, we are left without an effective response to these problems. Therefore, regarding the questions raised, I would like to add a few more.
We effectively want to address this issue as a public health problem or as a business.
Because if it is a public health issue, we must ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and for that, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to inquire, and hope it is not the case, whether we are expecting that, after all, the vaccine stocks in Europe will be so overwhelmed.
that secondary IFPs prove to be so negative in this plan, so that we can then truly have an act of generosity and, suddenly, start sending the necessary vaccines to the countries of the south.

Lastly, I would just like to ask if the European Union, we Europeans, and the Commission are comfortable with a system or model where Northern countries tackle pandemics through a prevention model, while in Southern countries it is treated as palliative care or with whatever is left over.

Mr. President, first and foremost, I would like to express my full support for the issue raised by Mr. Reul and, above all, to highlight the underlying issue, the fundamental political issue at stake in this matter, which concerns precisely the joint programming of research.

What occurred in terms of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, on Alzheimer's, was that during the process, the rules were changed. We went from having a report to having a resolution, thus eliminating our co-decision-making capacity in this matter. We ceased to be members of parliament and became consultants.
And, therefore, I would like to know if, at least, what we recommended will be taken into consideration or not.
The scheduling of research activities, regardless of the field, is a political choice, not a technical one, and in this regard, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they should be scrutinized, that they should be transparent, and that they should be democratic.
What occurred with the process regarding the joint decision and joint planning of the Alzheimer's research is a process that should not be repeated again, if it were to happen again.

Please repeat the request with due notice. Therefore, I hope that the last thing to happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations presented by the Parliament on this matter are not taken into consideration.
Mr. President, last month, the regions of Europe were particularly in the spotlight.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities highlighted the role of regions as a crucial part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.
Thus they concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samezky, and the hundreds of debates that ensued.

Also, at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the European Union's Ultra-Peripheral Regions, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy in favor of European integration.
Global challenges and European responses present an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for the OUTER regions (RUP).

These regions, such as the Azores, beyond the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that offer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give Europe a distinct advantage in new areas essential to addressing global challenges.

It is therefore demanded that the President of the Commission put a clear end to the palace coup that the Commission's No Paper indicates was being prepared, while we, MEPs and European citizens, were advocating the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in defending territorial cohesion.

I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteurs, in particular Mr Martin and also Mr Corbet. As a member of the EPP, I essentially agree with the proposed amendments to the rules of procedure.
It is essential to emphasize the point that seems important to me here, and which has not yet been raised here tonight, namely the role of national parliaments.
The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly stems from this regime and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also arises from its connection to national parliaments.
And what this Regulation or this proposal now seeks to do is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to strengthen democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the European Parliament's own instruments, its control mechanisms, and its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of national parliaments through various instruments.
And that is why I am, so to speak, fully in agreement with the proposals made.
I disagree with colleague Duff when he suggests that we should postpone the disruption of engagement mechanisms with national parliaments.
I believe we can do this right away, in light of the Treaty of Lisbon, and that this is very important.
I would also like to state that I support the proposal put forward by my colleagues Sayer and Brock concerning representation on the COSAC, and finally, that I am
I fully endorse the observations made here by my colleague Brok and other colleagues regarding the primacy of the Parliament and its Members over the Parliament's services.
Mr. President, Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I congratulate the rapporteur on the work done in this report and on her recent intervention.
This new microfinance instrument will enable the provision of microcredit to small businesses and to individuals who have lost their jobs and wish to create their own business and their own job.
This is of great importance during a period in which it is forecasted that the economic crisis will lead to the loss of three and a half million jobs in the European Union alone.

As a result of the economic slowdown, banks have stopped granting loans for job creation and business establishment, and access to credit has become more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinance medium will counter this current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of necessary funds for the launch of new businesses and jobs.
The proposal by the European Commission aims to reallocate 100 million euros from the PROGRESS program budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of PROGRESS resources, which targets the most vulnerable groups, is not by any means the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, there is support for the creation of a separate budget line to fund this instrument, as well as an increase in the appropriation to 150 million euros.

We also agree on the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group comprises vulnerable groups who struggle to enter or re-enter the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential for those receiving financial support to also have appropriate training. Thank you very much.
Many thanks, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating the Swedish Presidency, and in particular Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and the Portuguese EPP delegation.
Our assessment of the Swedish Presidency is one of nearly absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
Firstly, in the institutional sphere, the Swedish Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and to the highly successful election of the President of the Commission.
For, in particular, all ratification issues related to the ratification process, it was extremely professional and met the standards expected of best practices within the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution from the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the Commission's work was also extremely important.
We should say that, from my perspective and that of many PPE members, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the most success.
You are on the true global frontline of the fight, and this is due to the efforts of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Commission Presidency.
We also consider this balance to be very positive.
A third point is that of financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, took a step that we consider decisive and which could have a significant impact on exiting the crisis.
And, therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on this achievement of reaching an agreement in this field.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area that is very important to me personally, namely the Stockholm Programme and, consequently, the field of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that having followed both the tempering process and, in particular, the subsequent AIA process, I consider this Stockholm program to be absolutely essential, and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt on this.

Mr. President, as is well known, the recognition of professional qualifications was consolidated into a single legislative act, bringing together 15 directives, which has led to various practical problems in its application across the different Member States.

The difficulties are well-known, and the Commission should inventory the critical points and conduct an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the implementation of this important internal market provision.
The protectionist measures manifested at various levels constitute an obstacle not only to the free movement of people but also to the internal market.
We must attempt to identify the ambiguous points to ensure that the directive's effectiveness is not undermined by mistrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is a facilitation effort to be made that helps to dismantle professional corporatisms.
An improvement in the application of this directive should involve greater recognition of qualifications through the promotion of the SOLVIT network and the EURES network.
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points, and, no less importantly, it should provide a link between this directive and the services directive.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen of the House, it is urgent that we foster a debate on the Community budget and on how, in the future, we can contribute to its sustainability and transparency.

The post-2013 financial framework should be built on the principles of solidarity and territorial cohesion, crucial values for regions such as Madeira, which face persistent challenges and therefore require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking about and designing cohesion policy.

The Commission has, on several occasions, referred to certain aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and a more results-oriented approach in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that raise some concerns for me, especially when considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as, for example, value-added sectors.

A realignment such as this could jeopardize Objective 2, which currently benefits around two-thirds of European regions, not to mention potentially being counterproductive in regions with very specific economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, I believe that maintaining the criterion of proximity in cohesion policy is vital.

should continue to prioritize its allocation and management of structural funds from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even centralized European level. Thirdly and finally, but no less importantly, it is worth recalling and emphasizing Article 349.
Article 349 of the Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of the outermost regions with regard to access to structural funds, precisely because of their economic and social situation.
The situation is exacerbated by unique and enduring constraints and characteristics, which manifest in these constant difficulties and, as a result, require the claimed permanent supports.
Mr. President, given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen were several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than Kyoto, but it also created more divisions. As a result, what happened was that we ended up with a situation of every man for himself, where each state can define its own objectives, and moreover, in a voluntary regime.
It should be noted that having a two-degree Celsius target or funding targets without any clarification is also of little comfort to us.
And therefore, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future means moving from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always aspired to be a leader, and it has consistently affirmed this goal.
But, upon arriving in Copenhagen, he ultimately hesitated, failing to set or defend the goals he previously claimed as his own and which he said he would not negotiate.

And therefore, what I ask is whether, for the future, we will not be fairer, if we will continue to allow that, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest continue to pay the heaviest bill.
Mr. President, I would like to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at this very moment, where it is clear that the media is one of the main problems in the world.
Brought to light a government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which jeopardizes freedom of expression.
Just this week, a well-known journalist, Mario Crespo, had one of his columns censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the prime minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must provide substantial explanations to the country; he must clarify that he is not suppressing, nor successfully censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

In the way we are going, Portugal is no longer a state of law, it is a state of formal law, where the prime minister limits himself to formalities, procedures, and formalisms, and does not want to provide substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we aspire to a substantive State of Law.

Mr. President, the Green Paper on the reform of the common fisheries policy, for which my colleague from General Affairs, Maria do Celso Patrão Neves, is the rapporteur, presents a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector of great importance to the balance of local development in the outermost regions.

Madara follows with particular interest the ongoing discussion and deems it imperative to propose the differentiation between artisanal fleets and industrial fleets, which should benefit from distinct fishing regimes.
It is fundamental to advocate for a principle of positive discrimination, insofar as limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone solely to local artisanal fleets.
In forestry, priority is given to supporting the modernization of vessels, as well as management that ensures the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to prevent unsustainable situations for economic, environmental, and social balance.
Lastly, we will advocate for fisheries in the outermost regions to have permanent and non-time-limited support.
This report concerning the EAFRD aims to extend the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support was only applicable to marginalized communities residing in urban areas of the new Member States.
In other words, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and shelters, they could not benefit from support to replace poor-quality housing.
In essence, it is about how to kill a vaccine and provide Member States and their regions with greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also welcome the equal treatment of all Member States, as marginalized communities with support and integration needs deserve our attention, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon concluding the first reading of this significant report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid implementation within the framework of the economic recovery plan is also achieved, providing a swift response to the crisis that affects us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, allow me to begin by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his efforts in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the willingness he has always shown to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on amendments to the FEDER regulation that are of particular importance to the so-called old Member States and also to Portugal.

These changes will enable the extension of ESF (European Social Fund) usage in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities, as currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development projects.

The amendments that I proposed, along with other colleagues, and which were approved by a large majority in the Committee on Regional Development, will enable the former Member States, and not only the new ones, as originally proposed, to also benefit from this funding opportunity.
With this, I attempted to prevent the setting of a dangerous precedent that would exclude all former Member States from this and, likely, other additional uses of Community aid.
What would make absolutely no sense, given that housing-related issues, particularly among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old Member States alike.

I take this opportunity to reiterate that the length of membership in the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds, and that this criterion should be categorically abandoned.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, with a view to territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding, rather than punishing, regions that have proven exemplary in the use of Community aid.

Mr. President, at this moment, I would primarily like to emphasize to the Commission and to the President of the Commission the way they have worked with this Parliament over these past few months of the investiture process.

There is no organ in the world with executive capacity and legislative initiative that is subject to the presentation by its president of a program before the Parliament, and to a hearing with all the groups.

deputies to a vote by an absolute and expressive majority, to bring all the commissioners here to be heard one by one with their own program, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.
someone who agreed to negotiate with Parliament a framework agreement, in which they accepted, first and foremost, to justify and enhance Parliament's powers within the legislative initiative.

which accepted the principle of full access to information, whether in legislative and political action or in international negotiations, which accepted taking into account the Parliament's opinion on the Commissioners, on the reshuffling of the Commissioners.
This means, once and for all and from my perspective, that the Commission has demonstrated, since July, its willingness to maintain a close relationship with the Parliament and that it is

The President made it clear, in a vivid and unequivocal manner, that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method, as mentioned by colleague Sarkozy Zwolowski, is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
And therefore, the Commission and the framework agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Mr. President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to view this period as a missed opportunity.
And the blame is not solely on their political elites.
It is certain that these powers have been overly consumed by wars of power and influence.
that many reforms were left unfulfilled, many never went beyond the paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy, electoral laws should be changed between the two rounds of an election.
It does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them, or those who promulgated them.
and translate the little commendable and recommendable intentions in its genesis.
