Mr. President, let us be clear: the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt has neither worked nor is it working. The price of Greek debt has not decreased, and Ireland is in crisis.

The economic convulsions and contagion were not contained. The process that was established, came too late, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in a different format from the very beginning of the euro's creation.
The President of the Commission is now proposing to us a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments it proposes to use, it suggests involving the private sector.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a result of this premature and ill-timed announcement that the markets surged.
The Parliament will fully utilize its powers with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process accompanying the package.
legislative action on economic governance, but it will not do so at the expense of haste and speed, relegating quality to a secondary position.

Therefore, let us be clear, the Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the resolution of sovereign debt cannot be decided behind the backs and against the will of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are intertwined.
Lastly, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this time of crisis.

A European mechanism for the consolidation of sovereign debt is necessary, as is the issuance of eurobonds, and the eurozone must be sustainably protected through European, not intergovernmental, systems.
It is necessary to reinforce the European budget; we cannot continue with a 1% level of the European budget. Growth and real convergence must be placed at the heart of European political priorities.
And this agenda that the Commission and the new president must uphold
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I would of course like to state that the EPP's position is clear: it is a position that the Commission cannot act.
The resolution of this crisis, this severe crisis facing Europe and the European Union, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the communal method.

For us, there is no doubt that only with greater community method, only with economic governance, and only with the proper instruments of a true single currency in the euro area can this crisis be confronted and addressed.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament, assume their responsibilities before the Europeans.
And it must be said that it is clear here that at least the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate visibly with a view to increasing.
the community method of introducing economic governance, of providing the single currency with the necessary conditions to succeed in the face of the European crisis.

It is also evident today that the same is true of the Commission and the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what the Socialists and Member Elisa Ferreira say, have demonstrated that they are neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It remains for the Council, now in December, to assume its responsibilities.
It is on this that we rely, and on your manifest adherence to the European ideal, President Van der Rohe.
Mr. President, I would like to begin by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manescu on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for the Horizon 2014.
Today, more than ever, achieving economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for asserting the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that it is only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension that we can have a cohesive Europe internally and competitive externally.

In this particular context, I would emphasize three points that I deem crucial. Firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, are more involved and contribute to the better implementation of the cohesion policy.

invites the Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds, on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives, and finally, to strengthen the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management and implementation of programmes.
Only in this way, with the greatest involvement of these authorities throughout the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect I deem crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The underlying major concern of the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us not only do that, but also make your life easier by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that are deterrents to your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion.
Only then will we see the disparities within the European Union reduced, which are currently starkly contrasting with a huge gap between rich and poor regions.
Greater participation also means greater responsibility, and it is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better to achieve a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I begin by congratulating Edith Bauer and Anne Heth on their excellent work on this report.
Human trafficking disgraces our society and demands a robust and coordinated response from all.
The organized crime that lies behind sexual exploitation, forced labor, the trade in human organ extraction, and other ignoble practices must be effectively combated, but primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable people, namely women and children.
The experience demonstrated that the legal framework in place was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union needs to commit further.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective sharing of information and best practices.
In this proposal, a victim-centered approach is appropriately emphasized.
Policies in this field should encompass aspects related to social affairs and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore, allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country regarding this Summit.

At that time, Portuguese authorities prohibited the entry of European citizens into the country, and the only reason these citizens were bringing critical texts of the alliance with them was for this single purpose.
In these days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime, an authentic thought police, emerged in Portugal.
A regime so special that it prompted the Portuguese Government to purchase anti-riot gear worth 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are, after all, the priorities of a government facing a massive social crisis.
In the Europe we envision, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we envision does not bow down to military organizations that write their history in blood.
From the NATO summit emerged the legitimization of its military intervention across the globe.
The European Union's subordination to American military strategy and interests also emerged.
In third place, the militarization of access to energy sources was consolidated.
Lastly, the military defense of a development model was established, one that generates environmental imbalances and exacerbates social crises.
I therefore wish to say, Madam President, that in my view, with this summit we lose in democracy, we lose in freedom, and we lose so that some can profit from war.
Madam President, the first point I wish to make clear and which is important to emphasize in this Parliament is that the Commission cannot cease to be a speaker.
Contrary to what sometimes appears to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a difficult situation, with the currencies of the weaker countries undergoing massive devaluation and a potential German mark appreciating to a level unsustainable for the German and European economies.
And therefore, the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries in the eurozone, but also for the currencies of the countries that chose not to join the eurozone.

And for that very reason, because we have to defend this community that managed to respond to the crisis with no other like it, and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro indeed has advantages.

It is now our responsibility within this Council to do everything to defend the euro, specifically by creating a stabilization fund that follows the Community method and is able to introduce responsibility into

countries that are in a more fragile situation, and solidarity with those that have fulfilled their obligations and have not always shown, at least through their external statements, a willingness to be supportive in the context of the E-zone.

I would like to offer my sincere congratulations to colleague Sorbou for the excellence of the report produced, and I strongly advise that the Commission take it into consideration, especially in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which far exceed the strict scope of agriculture, is of great importance.

agriculture, require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market, and financial regulation, as well as others that also need to be addressed in other international forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The issues that are absolutely decisive for agriculture, for farmers, and for ensuring the availability of sufficient quantities and qualities of food for the populations of Europe and the world can only be effectively addressed if they are tackled in all their dimensions.

The ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the strict boundaries of agriculture and its goals are equally taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global bodies.
This report leaves me well-disposed, and I applaud it for that.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking you for all the words spoken here regarding the report that Parliament presents on Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are facing is substantially dramatic and is still greatly underdiagnosed, as has been mentioned here.
And I would like to mention just one issue that was transversal to all interventions, but probably not so underlined, which is the issue of patients' dignity and their rights.
and not only of the patients, but also of their families and caregivers, whether formal or informal, and of the professionals associated with this type of disease.

I am genuinely pleased with the words of the Commissioner, when he states that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations in the report presented by Parliament very positively, and will do everything in his power to implement them.
We know that each passing day is later than the previous one, especially given the urgency of the matter at hand.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow the Parliament will pronounce on this matter.
We will await the outcome of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral support.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us, and I sincerely hope, Commissioner, that you will then implement them, and that the Commission, which has the initiative and which, unfortunately, this Parliament does not have, will put them into practice.

All this priority given to this domain, which is transformed into legislative initiative, aims to ensure that citizens and their families have their rights respected and are treated with the equality and dignity they deserve.

or aspects that are internal matters of Hungary and which, at most, can be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Government and Parliament.

Very clear and very ambitious is the Hungarian agenda for this semester, by placing the focus and priority on three subjects that will be essential for the future of Europe.

food, which is now entering a serious global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and economic sustainability, and water, which has been little discussed but will be the next challenge for Europeans.

Madam President, I believe that these two countries, like others in the region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have often prioritized business over democracy, and dictators over the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the situation currently unfolding in Egypt and today's developments, which is why I believe that what we need is not calm, but solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens in Cairo and across the country, tired of hunger, tired of oppression, tired of unemployment.

And that is why, after today, after Mubarak's speech, after the regime's dogs have been unleashed, after a clear and open path has been created for violence, we must say that we need to stand alongside these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created to make them return home.
Thirty-six years ago, in Portugal, we would have returned home if we had heeded those advisories.
Fortunately, we didn't return, for we thus had a democratic revolution.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to say that I believe this issue is very important for us to continue living in the deception we have experienced in Europe.
Deception is a false promise, as it were, because we have been operating, especially in the collection of umbilical cord blood cells, based on misleading information.
And we know, as has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of umbilical cord stem cells does not reach its full potential.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases may be inexhaustible. Diseases such as those already mentioned, like cancer, Alzheimer's disease, and rare diseases, offer immense possibilities.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a network of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells and, from then on, at the time of birth, and from then on, cure them in the future, if necessary.
I believe we should be more responsible than that, because the likelihood of ensuring this happens is very low, as we know.
And this false promise, which is sold to parents, comes at a cost.
In Portugal, for instance, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly lies in creating public banks, terminal silos, because only with public banks can we ensure equal use, equal access.
an effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for all, and not just using stem cells as a commodity or a growing business that is only accessible to a few.
Therefore, I believe that solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, after all, things that can be classified as additional requirements.
We do not have the power to enforce, but we have the power to promote.
This falls within our remit, I believe we should do it in the name of equality, thank you very much.
Mr. President, food prices have reached an all-time high and this is the seventh consecutive time they have increased.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first of which is a short-term factor.
It has to do with the coincidence of poor weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two structuring factors, they are of a structuring nature, and that is why I am bringing up these two factors here.
The first aspect relates to the fact that some food producers and consumers who were previously exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
The second issue pertains to the ability of some large multinational corporations to manipulate price-setting in their favor.
And the example of cereals is this very clear level dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation thus places farmers in a state of great uncertainty regarding food product prices.
Europe must, therefore, resume doing what it stopped doing some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In the world where everyone turns to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
(SAMANTA) I will explain to fellow rapporteur Marisa Matias and acknowledge all those who collaborated with her.
Regrettably, in recent years, we have witnessed a rise in the counterfeiting of medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to European patients and the European industry.
The objective of this directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicines into the supply chain and thereby protect public health.

I would like to emphasize in the partnership I have developed the following key points: the introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, placing clear emphasis on consumer protection, and the application of the provisions.

safety for prescription medicines, the accountability of all stakeholders in the distribution chain, and finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr. President, I obviously want to thank all the comments made by all the colleagues, both male and female.
I will not comment on zoom 1, that is not the intention here.
I believe that if there were any doubts about what the word "commitment" means, it has now been made quite clear.

We may not all have the perfect proposal, but what is far more important than knowing if it is perfect is realizing that we hold an instrument in our hands that will enable us to no longer postpone the protection of patient health.
And we have the obligation not to postpone its adaptation either, we have the obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do this collectively.
I must also mention personally, and Commissioner has referred to the issue of inspections, that in my initial proposal, I tabled an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
The commitment is precisely this, and yet, one gains in some things, but loses in others.
We were explained by the Commission that this would be impossible to obtain.
I would like to make one more note regarding this commitment.
I believe that we all see ourselves in the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding in order for it to be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

In this commitment, safeguards are in place to enable us to monitor the process, assess, and systematically receive information that allows us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or not, and whether changes are necessary.

I therefore wish to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its cooperation, and in particular the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, with whom we have been working together over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions, there are flaws, but I believe we have a strong and robust commitment to enable us to fight for and defend patient health.
And since my intervention is also full of flaws, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, from the partners of the other committees.
Many thanks also for your support.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test of the euro's survival and, therefore, of Europe.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions, and for this reason, I also want to congratulate our colleague on the ideas presented.

The gravity of the moment stems not from the fact that the eurozone as a whole has an excessive external deficit or debt, but rather from the fact that the economies that comprise it persistently and severely diverge under the impact of common policy.
We lack tools that enable convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that enable Europe to grow.
Let us be clear, the eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies that make it up, with a budget of 1% of collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to construct was the recipe of austerity, and it is the workers and businesses who are paying the price today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, in the rescue of which 26% of the wealth of the European Union was committed.
The financial transaction tax, with a very low rate, for example, 0.05% on transactions of highly speculative high-risk products, it is true that they should be paid by their consumers.
But why should they not pay if ordinary citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk, and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed to harm fewer workers and businesses and be shared more evenly across financial sectors, especially speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I believe that it is not for the Commission, at this moment, to reject or evade the clear message that this Parliament is politically sending you.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions; on the contrary, it should be examined with the highest priority.
(FELIPE) We are well aware of what happened with the A flu, and this should serve as a lesson for everyone.
I don't know if you clearly remember how all of this started, but the truth is that it began in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the scale of the problem.
That is why the report voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the entire story unfolded, and who determined that it should have happened this way.
As we have the right to know which countries responded in a particular way, why did they respond without transparency and without allowing us to be informed?
The minimum of doubts, because we maintain all doubts whether or not there is a deal, we have to have the guarantee that no residue remains, whether or not there is a deal related to this flu.
That is why, Madam President, I understand that all threats to public health must be addressed, but it is not immaterial how they are addressed, nor who pays for them.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we are here discussing proposals on wages and proposals on the retirement age. The least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and who knows how many more countries, because this is an endless cadence, are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some things in common.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by stating that I fully support what my colleague has said.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of immense importance and growing significance, and the European Commission systematically presents a number of procedural intentions and timelines.
But there is a very complicated problem, as already mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but it does so in a very, very lengthy timeframe—nine months to a year—and this after the catastrophe has occurred.

As has also been mentioned, and as we have repeated and will continue to repeat exhaustively for as long as necessary, in the case of the forest, a year ago there was a huge catastrophe and it has still not received any support.
And I ask this, and I reiterate the question, is it not time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exception fund to address situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen, and climate change is here to prove it.
Therefore, the exception can never respond to a situation of regularity, thank you very much.
Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are highly sensitive and of utmost importance to our populations, and should not be overlooked.

We are discussing very sensitive situations that affect people's safety and their property, which often stir emotions due to the loss of lives, destroyed families, and the devastation of entire working lives.

Yet, all our demonstrations are of little avail amidst the dramas that, in a media-driven manner, impress and sensitize us all, if we then fall asleep on the job we must do to prevent, minimize, or better yet, assist in these situations.
Commissioner, the matter at hand is very well addressed by my colleagues.

It is an area where the European Union can best demonstrate its presence to its citizens, helping them in disaster prevention, especially when these occur, and standing by their side in the moments when they need it the most and are most vulnerable.
I would gladly respond, although I did not intend to turn a debate in the European Parliament into a discussion on Portuguese politics.

In fact, if Deputy Edita Estrela wishes to debate Portuguese politics, there is a simple solution. We should have elections, candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and the opportunity, as the opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies it intends for Portugal.
I will only say the following: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times over the years.
It is impossible, unsustainable, not credible to the markets, there are no more solutions for the socialist government.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating Mr. Schwab for his commercial persistence that led to this important compromise, and I also congratulate all those who collaborated with him on this report.

We aim not only to guarantee a high level of protection for European consumers but also to ensure that European businesses, regardless of their size, can supply goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal barriers.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation that has been hindering our companies' participation in the cross-border market and will provide a significant boost to the internal market.
The new provisions concerning the information to be provided to the consumer stand out, requiring this information to be clear, intelligible, and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements falls on the merchant.
As for contracts concluded at a distance, especially those completed by phone or over the internet, their rules should be defined, and consumers protected by simple and effective mechanisms.
We are confident that, at the conclusion of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will help make the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is imperative in a global economy.

Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, firstly, I would of course like to congratulate you on the outcomes of the Council of 24-25 March, particularly on the consolidation of the European Semester.

but even more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or the closure, let's say, of the Europolis pact, which had already been hinted at in the Eurozone summit of March 11th.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe, and it is only a pity that this process was not fully completed by March 24th.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the Member States had given that signal in the Council, by fully closing this reform package of the Fund, we would be in a different position today.

stronger to face the three, four months ahead, and partly we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also do not want to leave a word unsaid.
To state that, in the case of BPSD fully integrated into PPE, there is an absolute and total commitment to meeting the requirements and obligations of integration into the European area.
This is what we have been doing, even now, at this very moment, amidst difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the socialist government has done, the Social Democratic Party has demonstrated full willingness to provide Europe with any guarantees necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing domestic politics into the European Parliament, of the commitment, of the pledge, of the Social Democratic Party's full guarantee in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to adopt after its elections on June 5th.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Füle, the historic moment we are living calls for firm and determined action.
Like many of you, we are watching the events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin with a mix of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I am, however, satisfied with the proactive stance that Parliament is set to take regarding the review of the European Union's Southern Neighborhood Policy, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this region, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
Firstly, by asserting the absolute necessity of upholding our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the higher interests of citizens and their unwavering defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is imperative that this happens.
Only the greater involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express my frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not wish to seize this opportunity to finally differentiate the Eastern Neighborhood Policy with countries that could potentially become our partners in the Union in the future from the Southern Neighborhood Policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20th, the ambition that the current moment demands for a neighborhood policy.
Custom-made for each state, with clear benchmarks and careful assessment to lead to a future Mediterranean economic space with the new southern democracies.

In conclusion, Commissioner, we trust that the positive atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this subject will lead to a permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the reports we are discussing, for which I congratulate the rapporteurs today, reinforce a series of initiatives aimed at revitalizing the internal market.
I would like to emphasize the commitment of the European Commission, in particular Commissioner Barnier, whom I commend, and the positive reception of this Parliament through its
Consumer Protection and Internal Market Committee, to prioritize the competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the Strategy 2020.
Citizens and businesses anticipate effective impulses for Europe's economic growth to resume, they expect an increase in employment, and they aspire to create greater prosperity.

As the Commissioner emphasized, opening markets to our companies, by eliminating barriers and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and an unparalleled opportunity that will enable them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs, and their access to credit and the services market, as well as the European patent and recognition of qualifications, are essential.
the relevance of developing electronic commerce to strengthen consumer and business confidence in this type of trade, the focus on innovation.
Social entrepreneurship is crucial for robust and sustainable growth. It is indispensable in creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening, and fully exploiting the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, it is important to recommend that Member States redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also wish to add my voice to those who have expressed concerns about the low earnings of fishermen, exacerbated by the historic high prices of fuels, especially in recent months.

As has been very rightly pointed out here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, exacerbating the already fragile revenues from fishing with particular severity.
This alarming rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects: reduced trips to sea, meager earnings for fishermen, exacerbated by the low prices paid at first sale.

increases in imports from third countries of aquaculture and fisheries products into the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, with further job losses.
In this context, to prevent the continuation of the deepening of the crisis, it is necessary to act, and to act swiftly and thoroughly on fishing issues.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses, with both short- and long-term measures, to address the adversities facing the sector and the severe income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
Firstly, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our colleague from the EPP, Mário David, who is here today and is fully committed.

I did not have the opportunity to attend this plenary session, and I would like to state that we have always considered supporting the victims of the floods in Pakistan to be an ethical and moral imperative.
And therefore, we strongly support all measures that have been taken towards traditional humanitarian aid.
We truly believe that efforts should continue to be made to help stabilize the situation of so many millions of people affected.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered an appropriate and suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this has two dire consequences: one within the European Union, particularly for the southern countries and their textile and clothing industry, now highly vulnerable due to an unprecedented economic, social, and financial crisis since the...

And secondly, at a global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening of the world's largest trading bloc, which is the European Union, to potential Pakistani negotiations could completely destabilize the talks.
and it is no coincidence that they find themselves in the impasse they are in.

It is, therefore, natural that, faced with such a situation, we had to say, with regard to the history of this regulation and the difficulties it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations,

We collaborate with the most constructive proposals, and unfortunately, we now have to take a stance that will support the amendment which, in essence, calls for the end of this regulatory proposal as we know it.
We must do so at this moment, not out of lesser solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be provided in the proper place and in the proper manner.
President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, of course, I believe the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced one.
This is a very tough agreement for populations, but it places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I swear that this is very positive.

I do not adopt the stance of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland, and Portugal did everything right, made no mistakes, did not overreact, and did everything correctly, and that it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments have erred and pursued mistaken policies, but this does not mean that there is not now an opportunity, within the context of the Union, to have the possibility of getting back on the right track and the correct path.

Therefore, it is important to recall here that, in fact, one must inform public opinion, which is against supporting countries in difficulty, that they are not giving money to these countries, they are merely lending money to them.
But they are lending them at very high interest rates and, therefore, they are engaging in a practice that is beneficial for their budgets and their populations.
But I also say here that perhaps it is time for a comprehensive European response, with the introduction of eurobonds, and the possibility of primary market sales, to address international markets.

Perhaps it is time for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF to review interest rates, in order to provide the possibility of, by lowering these rates, seeing sustained growth in these countries that are currently in difficulty.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, and Madam Rapporteur, this strategy is crucial for all European countries, particularly those whose economies require enhanced competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises
Today, there is more active generation of new jobs.
It is essential for universities and laboratories, whose relationship with productive sectors depends on part of their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will find a new market in innovation as the traditional manufacturing model exhausts itself.
Innovation is at the forefront of the European agenda and, as a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, must be supported by new financial instruments to prevent it from succumbing to budgetary constraints.
Finally, I would like to acknowledge Judith Merkies for her significant contribution to a more innovative Europe with an economy more grounded in knowledge.
Mr. President, Madam President, and Madam Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The interim evaluation, although belated, highlighted the critical aspects of the seventh program: its excessive bureaucracy, industry disinterest, the number and complexity of new instruments, and the slow pace of disbursements.
There is also a greater risk of substantial transfers of funds from the current framework program to large-scale programs of questionable added value.

However, it also allowed for the highlighting of positive aspects: greater articulation and international cooperation among scientific groups in joint projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a more balanced gender representation.
There are priorities that should be developed first, simplification, secondly, promoting scientific excellence not in some countries, but across Europe, and fostering greater collaboration between

A framework program with innovation, featuring instruments targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar program, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, I will go straight to the proposal I am presenting to Parliament today, and I will tell you frankly that I believe we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because not only is it weak, but it also has significant gaps.
I believe this is a European issue, not a matter of states with nuclear industry and those without. It concerns all of Europe, and Europe desperately needs good news.
I, sincerely, must tell you that one of these good news items is assuring citizens that we are taking care of their security.
Now, when these tests are conducted as the Commissioner has outlined, that is, with a first phase carried out by the interested parties themselves and a second phase conducted by the Member States,

These stakeholders advocate for a third phase, carried out by peers who are genuinely interested. I wonder if the outcome won't eventually be to say that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and highly recommended.

We know this is not the case, and therefore, I sincerely hope that there will be serious consequences and that we can assure our citizens that we are taking care of their safety and not just pretending to do so.
I expect from this European Council, especially given the climate of recent weeks, a decision of great responsibility.
And it is a greater responsibility than that which existed in the last Council, where an attempt was made to postpone a problem for three months, solely due to electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision, which is essentially a matter of responsibility, makes it clear that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that these economic and financial matters are instrumental to what is Europe's primary purpose—the goal of maintaining peace.
If one approaches the problems in a way that merely leads to states beginning to distrust each other, to instill distrust among the different states.

create and accentuate differences and rivalries between the Southern States and the Northern States, between the central States and the peripheral States. What we will have led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of technical solutions, regardless of political drawbacks, is whether we believe or not that the European project remains a valid project for the peace strategy in Europe.
I believe that is the issue at hand.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both those in countries in distress and those from contributing countries, is that
among taxpayers, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to certain characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I appeal, and only to this, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a solution.

Madam President, Commissioner, my first words are to commend the work undertaken by the rapporteur, colleague Giorgio Stravakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness across the various structural fronts.

Your report also falls within this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that gains greater importance not only due to the substance of the topic but also, primarily, due to the timing of its discussion.
Indeed, we are now in the process of becoming acquainted with the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives but also concerning the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its instruments of excellence, the territorial funds, finances projects and programs in the Member States, aiming to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
Experience, however, has demonstrated the difficulties, in terms of both efficiency and outcomes, that arise from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

A single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for achieving greater and better synergies among the different instruments and enhancing their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination among various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in resource allocation.
We must seize the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is certain that all these reports we are discussing here today will present enormous challenges, and we know that to meet these challenges, we also need a good budget. However, we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
Political objectives are well-known, and indeed, it is by asserting these political objectives that we can offer a future for the regions.
And if this is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and citizens, and not the citizens and regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, the cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a single currency, requires, in order to function effectively, a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions.
The current competitiveness divergences, the development asymmetries, have inevitably led to the fragilization of the European space and the crisis affecting the eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a strong cohesion budget, one that cannot be weakened to fund other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must have more, and this is achieved by increasing its budget, not by reducing, even abruptly, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner whether the establishment of the Infrastructure Fund and the new innovation policies, which will be linked to cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, could become the Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security we require.
It is indispensable to engage all regions in this challenge.

To achieve this, the incentives provided for in regulatory systems should be enhanced, particularly those applicable to higher-risk and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores islands in the field of renewable energies.

Regions should be associated with the phases of awarding and implementing projects, in defining priorities, in their formulation and execution, as this ensures better results and thus a better defense of the European interest.
The current economic climate further emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is indispensable not to lose sight of its medium- and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens have access to secure, sustainable, and affordably priced energy.

Mr. President, the report we are debating is of particular importance, given the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

Collaboration with Rapporteur Próncias de Rossa was very fruitful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself has just stated, enabling the adoption of several compromises within the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.
For the result we have here today and which we have debated, I congratulate and commend the rapporteur.
In fact, from our perspective, the main concern was to make it clear that competencies in this matter lie with the Member States.
National authorities are responsible for defining, organizing, and funding social services of general interest.
Thus, the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level is unnecessary, given the significant diversity of these social services of general interest across the 27 Member States.

Simply consider the health, social security, employment, and social housing services, which are examples of how proximity and understanding of contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fair provision of these services.

Mr. President, as the rapporteur for the REGI opinion on the future of international social services, I would like to congratulate my colleague de Rossa, emphasizing the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we advocate for Europe, in which SIEG plays a crucial role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level advises against neglecting the existence of minimum protection levels in all member states, without prejudice to the respect for the competencies of their national, regional, and local authorities.

European regions play a very important role in providing these services to the populations, and their opinion should be taken into account, given the specific nature of their constraints, to ensure the delivery of these services to the populations.

In a time of crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing, international social services constitute a social safety net for the most disadvantaged or for those whose incomes do not allow them access to private services.

It is important to ensure that Member States which decentralize powers do so with the accompanying financial resources, so that regional and local authorities can guarantee their effective delivery to the population.
Madam President, Lady Ashton, I begin by stating the obvious: we must continue to support the democratic revolutions taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time, and therefore, I just want to leave a few notes.
Firstly, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition rather than civil war, must be defined by the peoples of these countries.
The situation in Syria is grave, this applies to Syria, but it also applies to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we wish to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to intervene and meddle in their internal affairs, especially and particularly through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, it is because we must totally repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have exceeded all resolutions, including those voted on by the United Nations Security Council.
It is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not included in this resolution that I cannot endorse it.

Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate the Polish Presidency on the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate them on

neighborhood policy not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I believe we are currently facing a challenge that is perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.
With that said, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay particular attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and financial market supervision.

I believe that at this moment, no matter how ambitious our objectives are in the areas of defense, energy, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multiannual financial frameworks, if we do not

If we resolve the issue of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid manner before the global markets, we will not have a Europe strong enough to face the challenges that the Polish Presidency has set out to address.

Therefore, I drew attention to the fact that it is crucial to convince the remaining heads of state and government that there needs to be greater economic integration, more economic governance in the European Union.

Without this, what will happen is that we, instead of being the leaders or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, or in Parliament, or in the European Interest Commission, instead of fulfilling this role, we will merely be
Mr. President, as chairman of the Mashreq delegation, I would like to offer a brief remark about each of my four countries, in quotes, of course.
Beginning with Syria, and reiterating here what some colleagues have also stated, it is regrettable that the international community appears to the public eye to have a double standard.

It is necessary to expose, if need be, the countries that in the Security Council, and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, in addition to Brazil, but with the right to veto, have prevented the international community from taking a more consistent position with the values we should share.
With regard to Egypt, I believe there is a pervasive need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities about postponing the elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, I believe it is necessary for this debate to send a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their actions in relation to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Under Jordan, it is an example of the fact that a peaceful transition is possible and that perhaps there is only a need, at this stage, to raise awareness and encourage authorities to accelerate the reform process.
In a debate of this nature, we must obviously not forget the peace process in the Middle East and reiterate our hope that the Quartet's meeting next Monday can be
indeed be productive and reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see much greater involvement by the European Union in the entire process.

I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will continue to constitute a reference point regarding recommendations and robust, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
The only conclusion one can draw is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome through the deepening of European integration.

In a time of severe financial, economic, and social difficulties and painful austerity measures, in some Member States, such as my own country, Portugal, there is a temptation to seek refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But, Gisele, I make mistakes.

The European response to the crisis requires a genuine European economic government pursuing sustainable growth, promoting job creation, and developing the social market economy. It should provide long-term solutions with clearly defined objectives that Member States can rally behind.
The crisis exit strategy needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avert a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination in fiscal policy matters is necessary, along with the establishment of a system for issuing public debt securities and euro bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that, during this challenging period, it is also necessary to maintain social protection levels, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, Presidency-in-Office, it is often said that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, this has been the case, but today I am not so certain that this remains true.

The slow, improvised, reactive manner in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis exacerbates the situation daily and spreads contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in an alarming way.
This, despite the Eurozone's problems stemming from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, now centers on its weakest links.

In order for the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is necessary, as there was in the past, and which, unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to instill in the program and the European project.
This report from the Parliament, however, offers us this more European vision, and it is indeed the solution.
The Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency create unbearable divergences between economies and that these must be counteracted by specific policies.

Acknowledges that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget with own resources, requires a European agency for the joint issuance of debt, capable of protecting states from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that the portability of diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require the mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament has united to send clear messages; let us hope that the Commission and the Council heed them.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear rapporteur, first of all, I would naturally like to congratulate and commend the rapporteur for considering this report extremely useful and allowing us to take new steps in the field of mediation.
The report provides an overview, a glimpse, of the solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, in the application of the
European Parliament and Council Directive 2008/52/EC of 21 May 2008 on mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Well, we all know the advantages of mediation.
on the one hand, it is a judicial mechanism for resolving conflicts, contributing to the decongestion of courts, the rationalization of the justice system, while at the same time providing
simultaneously providing the parties with the possibility of obtaining a friendly, faster, and less costly solution to the dispute in which they were engaged.

It is therefore noteworthy to reiterate the objective of Article 1 of the directive, which calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods, and in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

It is, therefore, a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security, and justice; I would say, for the concept of the rule of law within the European Union.
And it is for this reason that, in this context of crisis as well, I deem it highly significant that, as the report mentions, we can raise public awareness and engage stakeholders.
for this subject matter and call on the Commission and the Commissioner to rapidly submit a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to highlight the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency in the European energy market.
I merely wish to state that this is a central domain of cooperation in European terms, provided we safeguard certain fundamental dimensions, among them preventing
Liberalization translates into higher energy prices for citizens, ensuring equal access and being cautious regarding sanctions, as already mentioned by numerous colleagues.
Precisely because this is a central area of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot help but refer to it and question it, and ask you face to face, Mr. Commissioner.
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain yourself regarding the recent statements you made about Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, as these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures, such as flying the flags at half-mast, Mr. Commissioner, only serve to reinforce the shame felt by law-abiding citizens who strive for a better Europe.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Šefčovič, representatives of the Council and the Polish Presidency, firstly, I would like to clarify that I will be speaking here in a dual capacity, on the one hand, replacing the drafter of the opinion of the Committee on Social Affairs.

Constitutional Affairs, my colleague Nasser Schmidt, a Dane, who is absent as the election process is underway in Denmark at this moment, and therefore I am representing him as a member of AFCO, but also as a juror, as a shadow rapporteur on the jury for this report.
The first point I wanted to make is that, in the crisis we are facing, in the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation, of better legislation, is a central concern.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms, which can trigger the economic and financial takeoff of the European area, the improvement at the level of legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe which aims to be dynamic and competitive must have simple and accessible regulations for businesses and, of course, for citizens as well, and must therefore be tailored to their needs.
The truth is that, in this regard, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program for reducing administrative burdens be achieved, and that every effort be made to that end.
promote consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and companies, and conduct an impact assessment of the legislation itself, this is also extremely important, so that

The decision-making process can essentially be based, let us say, precisely on the opinion of those who are the intended beneficiaries of the legislation and can be carried out without administrative burdens and with lower economic and financial costs.

It is important to note that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the concept of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be appropriate and not one that promotes the complexity of the system.

and the regulatory system, and therefore, in our view, we pay special attention to the enhanced role that national parliaments now play in this dynamic, precisely due to the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is, therefore, essential that we also involve national parliaments, both at the level of smart regulation and in improving legislation, so that both legislation and regulations are aligned at the European level and the national level.

Be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient, and therefore, this is a good moment to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through smarter reasoning.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has continued to rise in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial, and social crisis, along with the rise in unemployment, have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is a denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity, and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for instance, which is subject to stringent austerity measures, the concept of homelessness, as per the national plan, includes individuals who seek assistance to obtain a meal.
And the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20 since 2008.
A more significant increase is noted among needy families and individuals whose living conditions have been altered by unemployment and also by banking indebtedness.
This is just one example that demonstrates the severity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament alerted to the necessity for the European Union to equip itself with a strategy underpinned by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending situations of people sleeping on the streets and the state of long-duration homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.
We took careful note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the point of view he presented.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong impetus to coordinate the action of the Member States and regional authorities to tackle this social injustice.
We discussed the peace process in the Middle East, but there is no ongoing process that I am aware of.
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union, in line with the majority of the international community, repeatedly affirms the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, entrenched in a spiral of hatred and misunderstandings that has lasted for 63 years, only extremism and frustration are fueled.

It is crucial that Europe and the Arab League become much more engaged in the pursuit of a negotiated solution for the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with the exchanges that allow the majority of Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the issue of Jerusalem, the holy city and future capital of both states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who are obligated to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that it is a land of milk and honey.

May all EU countries participate in resolving the issue of Palestinian refugees, and may the international community and, in particular, the Arab nation participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force, under the aegis of the UN and with the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be deployed as a guarantor of the maintenance of peace.
Thus, there is courage and political will.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, tourism requires a clear and coordinated European approach, with a keen eye on the potential and challenges that the different tourism models have to offer.
The tourist diversity that the European Union offers is so rich that it allows for exponential growth in this sector and in the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet on this key sector, which accounts for 10% of GDP and approximately 12% of employment in the European Union, will enable not only the creation of European added value but also the addressing of the economic crisis we currently face.
It originates from an ultra-peripheral region, Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

Therefore, the creation of a specific funding line for the sector within the 2014 financial framework is indispensable for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially made up of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a genuine European policy for sustainable and diverse tourism requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of enhancing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.
Mr. President, the absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing fundamental rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures by both sides, which do not need to be taken jointly.

did not contribute in any way to a reduction of tensions in the region, and even less to the effective pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

It is time for the international community to say enough, it is time for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution, with common sense, presenting feasible solutions without delay and with definitive deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us start with Jerusalem, why not revive the initial idea of a corpus separatum administered by the UN, which would obviously serve as the capital of both states?
Borders, we start with 67
Exchange your plots of land as much as possible and coherent.
Ensure the defense of Israel, an obviously unavoidable issue for the Jewish people, for example, by deploying blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces along the Jordan River.
There are approximately 4.8 million refugees, and they have the right to their dignity and to a future connected to a land, preferably their own.

But it is not exclusively an Israeli problem, nor a Palestinian one; it is also ours, it belongs to the neighboring Arab countries, to the Arab community at large, but also to Europe and the rest of the international community.
Colunatus must cease its expansion, and this is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and reflects hypocrisy and bad faith in a declaration of availability for immediate negotiations.

Above all, we want negotiations in good faith, committed, with a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to adopt a different approach.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, since the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has been mentioned, we all share, and I share greatly, what was said by my colleagues who have just spoken.
I will not refer to that in particular; I am referring to another, more overlooked situation, which is that of citizens who were welcomed into Tunisian families' homes.

And this is one of the situations that should shame us even more, because let's look at Tunisia, in a time of crisis, it knows how to be supportive. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not in a process of transition towards democracy; it does not know how to be supportive, it does not know how to welcome.
I find it, in fact, shameful that we can count on a few hundred the number of refugees received in Europe.
Many of these people, contrary to what has been said, cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the infrastructure level, and implications for the reception capacity of these countries.
That is why, Commissioner, I am very appreciative of what you do, and I say this sincerely, not ironically. But, please, what about the Commission?
And Europe.
What can it do?
How does Europe live so comfortably with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
It cannot continue.

Mr. President, I would, of course, like to congratulate you on this additional source of hope that you have provided to all European parliamentarians and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union whom we represent here.

And with that said, I would like to express that we now expect the Commission to take a very, very determined action alongside the Council, so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but immediate signals are necessary.

And therefore, without prejudice to the fact that we have already begun to think about a Treaty amendment that would provide the political translation for the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something needs to be done immediately.

This set of measures and, perhaps, an agreement among the States, what I have called a kind of parasocial agreement that goes beyond the Treaties and that can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into action.
Congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and leave here today with another decision.

Mr. President, the crisis that the European Union is going through has had severe consequences in all member states, and thousands of workers have been affected by the dismissals caused by globalization and the crisis.
We must affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and state that Europe should assist Member States in maintaining a high employment rate and combating unemployment.
Rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a top priority goal.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has resorted to it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalization Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to support thousands of workers through vocational training measures, business creation aids, and recruitment incentives.
This proposal is positive because it will enable Member States to request the intervention of this fund to support workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic and financial crisis.

We support the extension of the deadline and understand that it should be the Member States most affected by the crisis that have greater and easier access to this Globalization and Crisis Support Fund.
I greet the Polish Presidency and also Commissioner Wally Rehn, merely to state that I believe you

Today, building upon and advancing the measures outlined in the State of the Union address, a significant and substantial step was taken towards resolving the issues stemming from the Eurozone crisis.
Because the Commission has undertaken here its commitment to use its power of initiative and to employ it with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and is the only way we have at this moment to resolve the eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving in the short term, solely through an intergovernmental approach, and therefore it is necessary for the States, the state governments, to provide the
The Commission has the tools and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to implement, execute, and develop this roadmap that it has presented here.
But I do not want to fail to mention that this is not incompatible with what we do at the same time, with what we simultaneously develop in terms of our capacity to amend treaties.

I am also convinced that, in the medium term, the Treaties need to be amended, but even then, we must do so with the aim of strengthening the Commission, of giving it more power and a better position.

It is through the strengthening of the community metric, now in the short term and later with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve greater integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the eurozone and the 27 countries of the European Union.

Mr. President, Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that as one of the measures, banks that do not meet capital requirements must present plans to obtain them, and if they fail to do so, they should then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I cannot but agree with this presentation made by the chairman.
Just this week, we witnessed what happened with Banco Zexia, and a few months ago, a director of this bank received a prize of 600,000 euros for his supposedly wonderful management, as we know.
But, to be serious, the Commission President has to call on governments and present the full package, and the full package is what contains the essentials.
The essential point is that taxpayer money should be matched by a credit policy aimed at fostering growth.
The crucial point is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, notably in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or more accurately, in three years, this is the second time we are being asked to save the banks with taxpayer money, with the money of the unemployed.
(FEL) let banks also save the economy by aiding job creation. (SAM) Thank you very much.
Madam High Representative, there are times when I think I need little and to take stock, and this seems to be one of those times for me.
And it seems to me that this is because we always follow the rhythm of events and the response from one event to another, and we lose sight of the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case in itself and each country we are discussing here is a specific instance, but, forgive me for saying, High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize what criteria the European Union has employed to act upon each case.
I fear that we are often hostages to the interests of the countries of the European Union, on the part of some of these countries in the European Union and not all of them.
That is why we so often use the expression "double standards" in this house, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions yes, sometimes it is sanctions no, sometimes interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case in Libya, other times it is total silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by forces

There, Baroness, let me say that I have been carefully studying all the ACER documents, and I have yet to see a single statement from the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi Arabian military forces.

These are death sentences, endless violence, doctors and nurses condemned to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were allegedly opposed to the regime and not aiding the wounded who needed them.
With regard to Bahrain's dictatorial monarchy, and concerning the dictatorial regime in Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have seen far more silence than action.

I am not in favor of management, never have been, but I fear we are placing ourselves in an uncomfortable position, one that is perceived from the outside, Madam Baroness, where instead of aiding our development and aspirations,

democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in Arab countries. Instead of helping the first Arab era, what we do is prevent it from extending, whether by excess or by defect, and I do not think we should bear this sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yemeni activist can serve as a signal that our side is the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, this is a good report from colleague Casa.
First and foremost, one must ask why the VAT (Value Added Tax) in the European Union should be revised.
First of all, there is the need to align with the single market.
The more VAT rates and varieties there are, the less fluid the market will be.
