Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses in
with regard to the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, where the twentieth anniversary of this market was celebrated.

A first word of thanks to colleagues from all political groups, and in particular to the draftsman of the opinion and the shadow rapporteurs, for their very constructive contributions and their highly positive attitude.
It was a pleasure working with everyone, and the report greatly benefited from our combined efforts.

We are well aware and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been the driving force behind significant economic and labor opportunities in Europe, transforming the lives of European citizens and businesses.
Traveling, residing, and working across the Union's spaces are freedoms within the reach of all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our businesses, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which translates to more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress the single market has achieved in Europe since its inception in 1992 until the onset of the crisis,
In 2008, one only needs to look at the 2.7 million jobs created and the additional 2.13% growth in GDP.
Today, taking or receiving a TOEFL while traveling in Europe is cheaper than it was in 2005.
The free movement of people finds its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
Over 2.5 million students have benefited from this European education exchange and mobility program.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a reduction of 25 administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But a question arises: is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis affecting us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries, living with the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative perception of the internal market.
People still do not know or understand their rights sufficiently, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States unjustifiably delay in transposing European directives and legislation on the single market, thus hindering its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, seemingly simple matters such as, for instance, the reimbursement of medical expenses following a temporary stay in another EU country, or opening a bank account for a student participating in an exchange program,

Erasmus, changing energy suppliers, transferring retirement pensions, recognizing qualifications, and registering a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult, or burdensome procedures.
it is important to address these issues.
That was my concern, as the rapporteur.
Therefore, the message in the report is very clear: there is a need for more political will, much more political will from the Member States and European institutions.
Above all, the Council and the Commission must work together to govern better, by regaining the trust of citizens and businesses and by making it easier for them to exercise their rights.

Finally, I would like to greet the European Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, for the presentation of the Single Market Act II, 12 priority actions for new growth, which, I am sure, marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your efforts, already so successful.
During the presidency of Jacques Delors at the European Commission, the single market of the Union was established in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three fundamental principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years on, the economic and financial crisis has brought back the threat of national protectionism, and it has become evident that the internal market is not a finished product.

And the celebration of these twenty years must be seized as an opportunity to relaunch the single market, with a focus on putting the market at the service of the citizen, rather than the citizen at the service of the market.
For this, priorities must be established, and I would like to highlight one in particular.
It is essential to have a common policy for producing and distributing energy at consumer-accessible prices, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through a European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructure, with the possibility of leveraging community investment that represents added European value.
In energy as well, Madam President, it will subjugate the common market.
The greatest achievements of the European Union undoubtedly constitute one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its Member States, and its regions.
However, to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve the greatest development of our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue increasing their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions, but we will never achieve this if we do not better address our accessibility issues in the field of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best address the issues raised by our absence.
We therefore argue that the Commission should consider a specific program, similar to POSEI transports, as an essential instrument for integrating these types of regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to begin by expressing my sincere gratitude for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and one that demonstrated that the single market is indeed a great achievement of the European project.

I welcome the presence of Minister Mavroyiannis and his participation in this debate. I thank all colleagues for their constructive approach, and some for their skeptical stance, which is understandable.
And to express my sincere gratitude to Commissioner Barnier for his dedication and enthusiasm in addressing these internal market issues and for his political will to resolve them.
We still have much to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, they are disillusioned, and they expect more from us, they expect more from the Council, they expect more from the Commission, they expect more from the Member States.
This assessment is very useful, this 20-year assessment is important, but, as many have said here, it is crucial to open the door to future perspectives.
And the outlook for the future encompasses many issues raised here and numerous measures already announced by the European Commission.
The single digital market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, the European energy market are examples.
eloquent in indicating that we still have a significant path to traverse in the future, and that this path is of utmost importance and vital to addressing the crisis we are currently experiencing.
Citizens are suffering, and they expect a great deal from politicians and the responses they can provide to the adverse conditions they are facing.
Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the responses to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this 20-year celebration, are better equipped to provide the answers our citizens need.

Mr. President, the Gozez report, together with the report we will draw up on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year, which will anticipate the Spring Council, are two essential components of the so-called European Semester.
This report discusses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council, upon a proposal from the Commission. As just mentioned, these recommendations fall within the scope of
six pack and the future two pack, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policies of member countries.

Balancing and anticipating control, as well as autonomy and legitimacy at the national level, is not easily achieved. It has tilted towards a level of imposition, particularly of discipline, and ultimately may even lead to a serious package of sanctions.

With regard to the TUPEC, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent today, to give its negotiators a negotiating mandate that is in line with the ambition to quickly finalize this package, this TUPEC.

But more European coordination, returning to the subject, means less control by countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, focusing primarily on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be coherence.

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular regarding the asymmetric impact of common policies and the negative externalities of the spillover effects of certain national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is necessary for us to agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic, and labor rights that these recommendations cannot exceed. Lastly, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be assessed based on the results achieved, which is far from the case thus far.

I have already finished, Madam President. I would just like to thank Mr Gozez for his collaborative spirit and hope that he takes an additional step in this direction to broaden the consensus base around his report, and that this spirit also remains with regard to next year.
It is true, as has been often mentioned, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
But there are also many that we already know, and it is advisable not to forget them.
We know, for instance, that each shale gas extraction operation uses over 19 million liters of potable water, enough to supply 1 European citizen for an entire year in terms of their needs.

We also know that with each shale gas extraction operation, 300 pieces of cotton balls are pumped into the sun, along with up to 300 tons of chemicals, approximately 80 of which remain in the sun and do not leave.

We also know that, with each extraction of gas X, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, which, together with the evaporation of the toxic residues resulting from the process, pose a real threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources, and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we understand that the extraction of shale gas is also a response that is seemingly easy, focusing only on the immediate, industry, and profit, while ignoring populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this House, that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect citizens' health and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to prevent emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, both environmental and health standards.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, being informed is the least one can do.
And they might want to do so, but do not do it in our name, nor in the name of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, indeed, recent years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union failed to withstand the crisis.
We further demonstrated that we had a European institutional architecture full of gaps, particularly the institutional architecture of the euro.
That is why the report presented here and the proposal put forward are so far ahead in terms of vision compared to what is proposed by the governments.

However, as the rapporteur also mentioned, we are in the realm of making political choices, and this is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some concerns and will not be able to support this report.
The first has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to experience is a narrative in which solidarity among different countries can only exist when everything is fulfilled in terms of the stability and growth plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, the covenant for
a set of measures that impose nothing but massive doses of austerity on the peripheries, and also a set of recessionary measures that, as we have seen, are not working.
A second reason pertains to the banking union.
The rapporteur presents the banking supervision mechanism very well, but it is so necessary that we cannot avoid the essential, and the essential is escaping us as we continue to add up.

We are clustered in national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong, and therefore taxpayers will continue to pay.
And a third note concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of ordinary water emission is considered, but only when it is already too late.

Because we need common debt, and not just when excessive debt deficits have been corrected, because with the policies we are pursuing, they will never be corrected; on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire population.

Therefore, Mr. President, I wish to conclude by saying that, despite all efforts, I believe we have a very clear example here that together we could still rise, but divided, we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to have gone even further.
Madam President, Ms. Ferreira, please, there is always room for improvement, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union in recent years has been fundamental.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness relied on cheap labor to a country with a highly skilled and sophisticated workforce.
But when the country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for where.
Therefore, it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the requalified exports of countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to emphasize that it is not feasible for immigration to be the solution, nor for the retrained workforce, which benefited from European Union support, to be lost through the mass exportation of the most skilled to countries with the capacity to receive them.
This is dramatic and completely jeopardizes our future.

Mr. President, small-scale fishing should receive particular protection from the Common Fisheries Policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihoods of many families, but also because it is a factor that keeps these communities anchored along the coastal areas.
Its economic and social sustainability should be a goal, ensuring them a differentiated fisheries regime that prioritizes access to resources.
Enables local management and protects the fishing rights benefiting these community's professional fishers from transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important, for its sustainability, to consider the access regime to waters, especially in waters or regions with biogeographic basins.
navies with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that should have protected access.

In the context of liberalization and the crisis affecting fragile regions, it is also essential to ensure that products from international trade meet the same requirements as those imported by the Union.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, I will be very brief, because I swear that what is at stake here is essentially a political point, not a technical point.
A financial point and the question that arises is the following: whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or whether we want to exacerbate the crisis.

The majority of European countries are today making a huge effort, from the standpoint of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner, in a way that can position their countries

The European Union, on a global scale, is in a strong position in terms of competitiveness and competition. However, it is evident that without investment, there can be no growth, and this crisis cannot be overcome.

If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in the cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge effort to modernize and develop will be severely penalized.

For this effort, they will not be able to grow, and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union, with good accounts and prospects for growth and competitiveness, will fail.

The sole and primary instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework, and therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and for its policy to be a model for other countries, we must invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
